description.text: Main Project Page - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 I have this pretty cool tablet arm mount (2 actually), that I really wanted to replicate many of the joints in it for the qInch Project. The whole rig I put together works ok but I need to model a pretty good nob to tighten the bolts by hand. I used a wretch and some metal washers to tighten up the joints. I need some good thin metal washers inside the joints help tighten the joint. I used 6 inch bolts to make the arm long, its more shaky and all the weight means you have to extra tighten each joint. Its more stable with 3 inch bolts. But experiment with it. FreeCAD source included.

03-15-15 - End of the assembly and first tests of movement
03-03-15 - End of the modeling of the structure and plastic parts The original structure of Prusa i3 has many problems of backlash on the axes and must necessarily be recalibrated before each printing.
My project allows for a lower price a printer more precise and easier to assemble.
It is designed for full compatibility with the heated plate , steel shafts and belts purchased for Prusa .
I added two M5 bearings to tighten the threaded rods and reduce the backlash on the X axis.
I have also reshaped the extruder to scroll directly.

Illuminate your print bed without adding more weight to your effector!  
This solution uses self-adhesive LED strip lights available from most electronics stores. Be sure to get the ones you can cut to length. You will need (1) 25mm strip for each bracket (3 LEDs each strip).  
You will also need (2) 4-5mm longer bolts for your stepper motor for each bracket you add. I recommend one for each the X and Y tower.

• Print as many brackets you want to use.
    • Note: Mounting one on the Z tower is a bit of overkill, er, brightness.
  • Remove the top 2 bolts from each stepper motor and replace with bolts that are 4-5mm longer. For example, I used 12mm bolts in place of 8mm bolts.
  • Peel and stick the LED strips to the brackets.
  • Wire the LEDs through a switch and 12V main.

description.text: Yes, yet another spool holder for the Mini Kossel. I found a lot of examples I liked but none were exactly what I wanted. The one that came closest was http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:312624. This one uses the 50mm roller from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119016 (but you can change the size to fit your spools. This is designed for the 15x15 OpenBeam frame but you can modify it to fit your frame.

Vitamins:
(3) M3x8 bolts
(3) 5/8" washers
(1) 5/8" nylock
(1) 5/8x5" bolt Print out the mount and the roller from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119016. The mount prints with included supports. Cut those away before installing. The mount is designed to mount to the Z tower using (3) 8mm M3 bolts. You can drop the nuts down the frame from the top. You then mount the roller to the bracket using a 5" 3/8" bolt and nylock. Place washers between the roller and the mount as well as between the nylock and the mount.

This creates a fan mount and nozzle for a Mini Kossel  
I wanted a print cooling fan for my Mini Kossel that used a squirrel cage fan mounted above the effector. This is my solution.

Vitamins: (1) M3 nut
(1) M3x25mm bolt
3" of 18mm inner diameter flexible hose. Used medical air hoses work great. Just ask your local medical supply store for a used CPAP mask hose (not the long one that goes to the machine, the one that attaches to the mask - they'll know. ;)
(1) 12v 50x50x15 squirrel cage fan
A bit of wire to wire in the fan to the part fan port on your RAMPS (or equivalent). Don't wire it to main, you don't want this puppy running 100% all of the time. It will cause extrusion failures and other unpleasant things. The height of the .stl is 64mm as measured from the top of the effector. To change this, edit the .scad file and modify the call to fan_duct(). Instructions:
  • Print each component.
    • Note: You can print the fan mount in PLA, but you should print the nozzle in ABS. Note: the nozzle is 63mm tall, which mounts to the top of the effector. Measure the distance from the top of your effector to the bottom of the heater block on your nozzle. If this is 62-64mm, you're good. Otherwise, open the .scad file and change the height as needed.
  • Insert the M3 nut into the mount. If loose, use a bit of super glue to hold it in place (you won't be able to get to it during installation).
  • Secure the fan to the mount using zip ties.
  • Slide on the hose to connect the mount and nozzle.
  • Remove the rear-most bolt from your effector holding the hot end in place (or whichever point you want).
  • Assemble the fan and secure the bolt.
  • Wire the fan to your electronics board.

title: Storage handle screwdriver for magnetic chuck.

description.text:
This is a refined, fatter version of the storage-handle screwdriver I did previously. Works well with the magnetic shaft, like included with this bit set or something similar that often comes with a cordless drill set; this gives you a screwdrier with a handle for better control and portability than an electric drill. It supports use of a 3/16" cylindrical magnet to keep the chuck stored in the handle or locked in position.
It feels good in your hand! Drop me a note for questions or comments.

I made it on my lightly modified Makerbot Replicator 2: 245C extruder temp, .3mm layer height, standard movement, raft, 75% fill, with a heated bed at 45C. I had a little bit of trouble with the print separating from the raft, so I paused at about four layers and painted the interface with slurry. It came out nice. Use a 3/16" cylinder magnet to keep your chuck in place. To insert the magnet, just stick the flat side, centered on your chuck and press it in from the "use" side (not the storage handle side). You may need to work the excess printed material out a little to get it sliding in and out cleanly; the magnet should be what holds it in place. The handle recess is 5mm longer than the chuck shown; the idea here is that you smack it briskly against your palm to dislodge it; it works for me.

author: PocketBrain

description.text: This is an adaptation for the Mini Kossel with 15x15 frame components that allows you to mount your RAMPS to your lower frame. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:567088 to get the lid.

Print 0.3mm layer height and 20% inflill.   
Attach the body to your frame before inserting the RAMPS boards.  
Route all wiring through the slot and between the frame members.  
Makes for a nice clean install.  
The extra switch and momentary button are farkles and not needed. In case you're curious, I added a reset button (not needed if you have a LCD panel) and a switch to switch the fan from 12V (high) to 5V (low). Again, not needed. Use a low-flow 40mm fan and you shouldn't need to throttle it. ;)

This is a collection of parts I have used to make a real simple Filament Spool Holder. I wanted a "sit on top" design that hugs the 2020 Aluminium Extrusion.
Some parts are from other designs here on Thingiverse. Parts Required - (all supplied here .. but sources also below)
  • 2x Cone Spool Bearing Supports - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:144353
  • 2x Support Arms - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:165150)
  • 2x Bearing spacers - (sized 8mm inner, 11.6mm outer to match bearing) - (When mounting two spools I have not used these spacers)
  • 2x Insert Collars for the Support Arms (to fit 8mm rod perfectly - 8mm inner, 13mm outer)
    • Hardware
  • 1x 300mm threaded 8mm Rod (Screwfix in the UK)
  • 2x M8 / 8mm Wingnuts
  • 4x 8mm large-ish flat washers
    • Enjoy

Insert the "collarinsert.stl" on the outside of each arm. This will support the 8mm rod.  
I had one filament spool whose inner hole diameter was smaller than the 608_hub_2. I just used a forstner drillbit on a bench drill to make the hole the right size either side. (quicker than cading up a new piece)  
I had to "drill" out the hubs and spacers with an 8mm drill bit due to the rough insides. (just made them slide on and off easier for a quick change). Otherwise you will find yourself screwing them onto the threaded rod. It is important that the Hub can rotate smoothly.

For use on cane with 22mm dia shaft.  
I designed this to replace the one that broke on my cane, and print in PLA to cast in bronze.

For those of you who don't know, you can do Lost PLA casting, much the same way as lost wax.  
This process involved first printing the file, then spruing it with wax, pouring investment and letting it cure, then burning out the wax and PLA to leave a void in the shape of the cane head.   
Molten metal is poured into the mould, and because this particular piece is a larger bronze cast (about 1 troy pound) it was left to cool instead of directly quenching it in order to avoid fractures.  
The pictures you see where it is dark are from right after it was removed from the mould, and I began to remove the sprue, and grind the hard edges soft.   
Some of the PLA didn't completely burn out and there were gaps which I filled by hammering bronze into them and soldering it into place.  
Once it was cleaned and polished, I coated it in paint, then scratched the texture into the paint. I followed this by immersing the piece into ferric chloride which is an etchant. 2 hours or so later, I decided that the etch was deep enough, and removed it. The final product you see there is after a sandblast and a final polish.
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

12/20/2013: Don't use this thing, use this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22422 I modified the SCAD file to have 0.5 gap sizes and a z_rod_r of 7/2 instead of 6. I also need to enlarge the 3mm nut and screw holes but I really like the design.

Update, the fixed file has been uploaded, sorry for the prior issues. Update: Apologies, not sure what happened to the V2 file to make it corrupt, but I will rebuild and re-upload this evening. I have removed it to stop anyone else from wasting their time. Update: I added setscrew to the motor shaft end. The vibrations would walk the Z axis down slowly. This stops that. I also make it smoother to take advantage of Sprinter's speed. The old version:
I edited the coupling.scad file to increase the outer diameter and thus wall thickness of the part. I also added hex recesses to capture the nut for the clamping screws. I had issues with the originals splitting. I think it's because I used PLA (I only use PLA) so you may not need this for ABS.

I used a high fill rate for mine (50%), I wanted them solid. I also changed the diameter for the M8 rod and use 7.5mm which for me was perfect and allowed the 5/16" rod to thread into the coupler snugly.
I used a hacksaw blade to cut the bridge material at the split, it's the perfect thickness.

description.text:
This thing creates a low-profile glass clamp for a Mini Kossel (or similar small delta printer).  
This will fit a 170mm build plate. It is NOT FSR friendly, but is Kapton heater friendly.  
It has spring-loaded clamps for holding the glass in place. Depending on the size of your hot end nozzle and heater block, it should clear the heater block and not reduce build diameter. However, you may want to experiment and reduce your build diameter if there is any chance of collision. I have included a lower profile clip for those printers with larger heater blocks (or other obstructions).

Vitamins:
(6) M3x6mm bolts
(3) M3x25 bolts (you can use 20mm but they're a bit too short)
(3) M3 nylocks
(3) M3 washers
(3) bed springs (or extruder door springs). Stiffer is better. Instructions:
  • Print out (3) clamps and (3) bases. Bases will print with supports already added. Clean out the supports.
  • Install the clamp to the mount by threading the bolt through the clamp and mount then add the spring, washer, and nylock. Tighten so that the clamp can move with moderate effort.
  • Install the mounts to your frame. Don't tighten the bolts yet.
  • Insert the glass and adjust mounts so that it fits snug and level.
  • Tighten the bolts on the mount.

The Automatic Affirmation Device only has one thing to say:
YES.
Will today be a good day? Will I pass that exam? Is this the best idea I ever had ever?
YES.
The Automatic Affirmation Device is your own personal confidence booster that is never wrong. This is designed to be a gift, the perfect gift, (for you to give) to someone who is in need of some caring reassurance.

The Box itself

  • Print out all three sections of the box:
    -The Base (Base-Battery-slider.stl)
    -The Lower Section of the Box (Lower-section.stl)
    -The Top Section of the Box (Top-section.stl)

  • Attach the top and bottom sections of the box to each-other. Be sure to carefully align the sections so that the front face (where YES is displayed) has a clean seam. I affixed the two sections together using ABS glue, but I imagine Hot Glue would also work.
    • The YES Screen When the interior light is activated this is the 'screen' on which 'YES' will be displayed.
  • As shown in The YES Screen Components image http://www.thingiverse.com/image:47017 there are three basic elements you will need to make/find:
    • -A small piece of paper with the word yes cut out of it. Once cut, I painted mine with acrylic paint so that it would not let as much light through the paper. (I included a YES graphic in the list of images for this thing, but i don't know if that is actually making things easier for you...it's not hard to design yours better than mine and the size of 'YES' will vary with the box size) -A small piece of tissue paper. Yellow or Green will work well. -A green coloured piece of plastic (You could use coloured acetate, for mine I printed out a green rectangle onto an overhead projector sheet). the outer size of these sheets should be about 46mm x 23mm, but that will vary depending on the size you printed your box (just make it small enough to fit inside of your box, but large enough to have something to glue on to the box interior). The word YES should be small enough be visible through the tiny window on the front of the box.

  • Using a glue stick, or some rubber cement, affix the tissue paper to one side of your green coloured piece of plastic.

  • With the plastic side of the screen facing downward, affix your paper with 'YES' cut out onto the tissue paper side of the screen.
    • when glueing down the 'YES' paper, the word should appear backwards as seen in the image of the box's interior http://www.thingiverse.com/image:47018
  • You can now glue the 'YES' screen on to the interior of the box as seen in the previous image. Note that plastic side of the screen is facing the outside of the box.
    • Note that I painted the interior of the box with acrylic paint to prevent light from escaping. The Electronics The electronics are very simple, and are wired as follows:

  • With some copper wire connect one lead of the battery to one pole of the bulb holder.

  • Connect the other lead of the battery to one pole of the momentary switch (note: depending on the type of switch you purchased you may have to attach these wires after the switch is mounted in the box...which is tricky, but doable).

  • Connect the remaining poles of the of the lamp and momentary switch to eachother.
    • Sidenote: As a simple as the electronics are I am sorry if I completely failed to properly articulate the steps. Also, I am sorry if I insulted your intelligence by trying to carefully explain what is a pretty bare bones circuit. As an exercise for myself I attached a schematic image onto this thing...I understand that schematics are easy for most people to read...but they always pose a difficulty for me. The extremely simple schematic I attached is the first one I have made that is not a collection of arrows and squiggly lines, handwritten on a piece of crumpled paper, that I eventually misplace. Finish it up Once your switch is mounted into the box, and the battery compartment is hot glued on to the Base Battery Slider, and the 'YES' screen is glued onto the interior of the box, you are pretty close to being done! You just have to mount the light in place. My way is not the best way, this is what I did: I glued a small dowel on to the interior top of the box, and used that to pivot/position the beam of the light, which was then hot glued into place. It was a little finicky, and maybe your derivitave will include a light mounting thing in the top-section.stl ;) In my own box I meant to use AAA instead of AA batteries, but I only had one size of battery holder on hand (You will find that I often trade a patient solution with a quick solution, for better or worse). With the smaller batteries you will likely have more options for light mounting and battery positioning. Also, I only had a prefocused light on hand, which isn't the best in this situation. To increase the spread of the light I put a dab of hot glue on the lights tip (you will also find that I solve ALOT of problems with hot glue) to properly diffuse the light. Also note that the battery compartment is glued close to the front of the Base Battery Slider: http://www.thingiverse.com/image:47019 AND THERE YOU HAVE IT! YOUR AUTOMATIC AFFIRMATION DEVICE IS BORN Operation
  • Ask the device a question that you need to be positively reassured about.
    • 2.Press the momentary switch on the top of the device.
  • It will only tell you the truth.
    • Presentation When you give these devices as gifts to your friends and family it is important that you believe in them. You absolutely need to take on the role of artist/magician/TV Infomercial salesperson. The box itself is only a box until you transform it into art through your presentation.
    I believe in you.     Tell them that this is The Automatic Affirmation Device. It is made for people who need a little confidence boost from time to time. It says the perfect thing in your time of need. "Will today be a good day? Will I pass that exam? Do people like me? YES. The Automatic Affirmation Device is your own personal reassurance device, and provides you with consistent and precious affirmation". -Max Lupo
    http://www.maxlupo.com

Print your own NFC Tag, many usecases! http://bitnfc.org/ Download BitNFC, the easiest way to scan and write the coins (developed also by me @ 720kb) An NFC tag can be used as a bitcoin wallet, this way you can literally 3d print your own money. Watch the demo Youtube video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XvkjrJfUNgQ NFC Tags programmable with (examples):
  • Private Key (5....)
  • BTC Address (1...)
  • bitcoin:1Address
  • text (hello btc)
    • 3D Model Featured on World Crypto Network
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9jljUiVXg6g&feature=youtu.be&t=58m20s BitNFC video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=srE1fDB-dTY DogeNFC - dogenfc.com
    repository (code): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9jljUiVXg6g&feature=youtu.be&t=58m20s Mini Kossel V-Slot video printing it @ 90 mm/s: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yFjw6WXUtZY

x1 NFC Tag (they are cheap on amazon or aliexpress, 30 cent/each, if you ar not sure about the type for the compatibility, search "NFC tag android")
x2 Bitcoin NFC faces normal size 3D printed - Diameter ~42.2mm
  • Stick the NFC tag behind one flat face of the printed coin
  • Put glue around the NFC tag and stick the other face

  • Keep it pressed (under a book or something)

    Glue them together with instant glue or some other glue that reacts well with platic
You can also print a coin and while it's printing (if your printer supports pausing it's better) stick the nfc tag into it, this way the tagwill be embedded inside the coin / object.

To write the NFC tags you need a phone with NFC, we made an Android App that makes the process easier: http://bitnfc.org Windows Phone version coming soon! otherwise you can use
"NFC Tools" for Android (play store) or a similar app
to manually save the private key into the coin Dogecoin version is being developed at: dogenfc.com (soon!)

Fully customizable pseudo 7-segment display.  You can specify the orientation, number of digits, size, and angle of the display.  I printed the segments in dark-blue and "glow-in-the-dark" light blue for use as house numbers.  The provided stl files are for 2-digit 90mm tall panels; but you should generate your own from the openscad files.   
This thing can be used as-is as a sign or incorporated into other designs.

I tried to thoroughly comment the scad files, so you shouldn't have too much trouble customizing them.  
Generate your custom plate from 7segmentPlate.scad first.  Watch the output, it will tell you what size to use for the segments.  Using that value, generate the segment stl(s) with 7segment.scad.  You will likely have to adjust the size a little bit for your particular printer.  
If you are producing angled digits, you will need as many as four types of segments, two types of "unlit" segments and two types of "illuminated" segments. The vertical segments use the value you specified for the plate. The horizontal segments always use an angle of 0.  
If your digits are not angled (0 degrees), the horizontal and vertical segments are the same.  
Further customizations are possible,  You can also change the thickness, border around the digits, and space between the segments. It is not difficult to alter the scad file so no openings are generated in the plate for the segments that are to remain "unlit" if you prefer that look.

This is a PS4 controller mount I made for the same "Clip System" I made for my headphones. (here: ==>>http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:693980)
The main base clips onto the glass table, then the mount part slides into that clip and the hooks press fit into the mount. With a series of main base clips made, you can move the mount all over the place by simply sliding it out of one and into another. Update: enclosed the push fit hole to be more robust; created a new base with leg locations spread more so legs wrap outside of the controller sticks. This makes the holder much more reliable and the controller does not easily get bumped off like it used to.

title: Buildable Dog House v3 (w/ porch and side paneling)

description.text:
Scaled down (scad files use actual sizes, I scaled it down in the assembly scad files) of a 5 feet by 3 feet dog by 3ish feet dog house. Uses mainly imperial units as the lumber (AFAIK) is in imperial units where I live (USA).  
Still a work in progress, designing it for my lovable pup! Hoping to add on a side panels, moulding, feeding area, strorage area, and porch attached to the front of the house.  
The scad files should contain the proper dimensions to build the actual full size dog house, although for the first like 70% of files I was converting all imperial units to mm, but by the end I just found it easier (for my when I start building) to use the imperial units and multiply it by the conversion factor (25.4) so in some files there will be mm and some will be imperial * 25.4.  
This is my first woodworking project as well, so hopefully things go well :) I guess it's possible to scale down the individual scad files, print them out, and glue it all together!

title: Rushmore Pins - Perfect Attendance & Punctuality Award

description.text: I went to a costume party dressed as Max Fischer from the Wes Anderson movie Rushmore, and thought his lapel pins would be a nice touch.  So I made some to be cut on the laser cutter.

The SVG files are my Inkscape originals.  The EPS files were exports so that I could open them on the laser cutter.  The CDR files are Corel Draw projects that are resized and saved.  The mirrored files are reversed so I could cut on mirrored 1/8" acrylic.  I painted the backs with red paint pen (as red as I had - it's more of a rose color than the proper cardinal) and glued on pin backs/clutches.
I used Gorilla glue and clamped the pin backs on overnight.  They don't show through the front and the glue seemed compatible with the paint.

I'm going to call this an "educational" brushless motor because last time I checked PLA isn't ferrous (I can haz magnetic domains?), the rotor is using flat magnets (I can haz more flux?), and the rotor should be 1 angstrom away from the stator but... its not. Here is a video of me only firing one commutation state: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbubtBy1UJg You can print all these parts without supports.

Alright you want to make a badass motor? Then listen up...
Step 1. Go to the hobby store
Step 2. Ask them for a 5HP DC brushless motor
Step 3. Give them the money which you made by working hard at that IT job.
Step 4. Using the ideology that money is just an exchange of labor take credit for building such an awesome motor. Now if you want to make the motor shown above then get the following materials:
Item 1: Transformer winding wire.
Item 2: 12x 0.5"x1/16" rare earth magnets (you may have to beg China by the time you are reading this)
Item 3: 2x 0.625"OD and 0.25"ID bearings, I tried inserting 1.75mm steel wire into my replicator 2 to print my own bearings but things didn't go so well and now Makerbot wont return my calls.
Item 4: Patients... I hope you have a Lord of the Rings marathon coming up because you're going to be winding this motor for a little bit. Print/Assembly:
DO NOT PRINT: the magnet.stl and bearing.stl
These are just to help you find the parts/get an idea. Print:
1x stator.stl
1x stator_top.stl
1x stator_bottom.stl
1x rotor.stl
2x shaft.stl - May want to print these with a higher infill % Assembly:
First wind the stator, so how do you wind the stator? Well i'm glad you asked:
Step 1: Go to the hobby store... wait... no... Get yourself some masking tape and a Sharpe (not the dog). Choose your favorite stator "arm" that you want to wind first and using a marker and the tape mark that one "A - CW"
Step 2: Now the stator arm straight across from the one you just marked, mark that one "A-CC".
Step 3: Choose an adjacent stator arm to the "A-CW" one and mark that one "B-CC"
Step 4: Now the stator arm straight across from the one you just marked, mark that one "B-CW"
Step 5: Alright two stators left... I bet you can guess what to do next because... hell you're a maker... and a damn smart one too. But just to make sure "your friend" (wink wink) does it right I'll tell you. Choose the unmarked stator arm next to "B-CC" (should only be one) and mark that "C-CW"
Step 6: Only one stator arm left... mark it "C-CC" Now what the hell was all that marking for? Well A/B/C are your phases and CW represents "Clockwise" and "CC" represents "Counter-Clockwise". So when facing the stator "arm" straight on that's the direction you're going to wind the wire. On each stator arm I did about ~300 turns, remember the more turns the less educational and more badass this motor becomes. When winding each phase (A/B/C) you want the wire to be continuous from the clockwise arm to the counter clockwise arm hence all the little pegs to run the wire around in. See my crappy drawing or "schematic" above. Now that each phase is wound (English is nuts wind transformers in the wind, while your friend wound transformers with a wound) solder "A-CC", "B-CW", and "C-CC" together so it resembles the schematic. End caps:
Now pop the bearings into the _top.stl and _bottom.stl parts your printed... they should fit pretty tight, may need an exacto blade to get it just right. Rotor:
Taking your 12x magnets, place them into the rotor like shown in the image above so you have one side "North" and one side "South". Take the two "shaft" parts and slide them into the rotor, one side should sit flat while the other sticks out just a bit (0.025"). The part that sticks out should point towards the stator nubs. Final:
Slap the whole thing together, get some manly N-Channel and P-Channel MOSFETS, an Arduino for the blog cred (credit: xkcd), and get that baby commutating. I'd suggest looking online for how to put together a 3phase H-| (terrible joke) bridge to drive the motor. To commutate the motor through its six states you want to apply V+ to the first letter and GND to the second letter. For example:
AB - Means A is at V+ and B is at ground. Here are the six commutation states
AB, AC, BC, BA, CA, CB (and repeat) Faster you go through those six states faster the motor will spin... but remember to ease into the faster speeds or your rotor wont be able to keep up and all your friends will laugh at you. Oh and the mounting holes on the end caps are meant to be 4-40 tapped.

description.text:
I want to add a shelf to a small desk and I made this support so that I can use a piece of some home depot 1.5" x 2' ABS SCH 40 CUT PIPE piece. It's what I bought since it wasn't too big in diameter but strong enough for a small shelf to hold a lamp, soldering station and small charger. This was plenty for two supports. So you will need to at least print four of these or however many you need depending on your shelf. Note:
I just put the shelf together and it's lose and wobbly, so don't use this just yet. I'm making a few changes and will update once that is done to make sure it's more stable. Okay, I have fixed this and now the pvc fits the way it's supposed to. There is now more support on the height. I also increased the base by 3 mm to give it a bit more surface area. So you should be able to make a nice shelf now. Sorry about that, I had not built the shelf but now I have and it works. The file old file has now been replaced with the updated one.

This was printed on a craftbot 3D printer. I used the default settings of .200 mm/s and 220c/60c bed temp. So the higher resolution may give you an even more rounded diameter. I used the medium setting and I think this will work for me since once the rings are screwed down it should not move and my shelf is pretty small too.  
The good thing is that if you cut your pvc too long, just pull the shelf up, take out the pvc and cut again to whatever height you need the shelf at. Let me know how it turns out in the comments or any constructive feedback is always welcomed. I will add a picture once I get it finished.  
Just make sure to measure the center of the shelf anywhere yo add these so that they all sit aligned in the center. And also measure the bottom supports too so that you don't have to drill one too many holes. I got lazy and just eye balled it and had to make a few more holes.

extension cord spool

I have many of these short, inexpensive 2-wire extension cords, from 6 to 15 feet long. Photo shows the taller, 4 inch diameter spool comfortably holding a 15 foot (4.5 meters) cord.
Sections are heavy at around 1/8 inch (3+ mm) thick, because mine will probably be treated roughly, out in the garage. The larger print took 110 minutes, used 87 grams ABS, using Afinia's defaults, except for selecting 0.40 layers to reduce print time.
(The cord_spool_small.stl version holds about 8 feet of cord. ...80 min, 60 grams) About half of the ABS of either version is wasted on raft and support.
Afinia software says one might reduce that waste by half if it's printed on edge, but I haven't tried it, and probably won't. I prefer the horizontal layer orientation. Note. These files are SAE / Imperial. As I understand things, after importing these STLs to some print software, they will appear very tiny.
To size them properly for such metric printer software, scale up by a factor of 25.4.

Found some lenses on amazon and decided to buy them to see if they would work to create a VR Cardboard goggles. Just a frame I modeled really quick that allows me to adjust the spacing between the eyes and the distance away from the phone to test out if its possible for me to make a pair of goggles. Pain in the butt to calibrate something like this but its something small that prints in 30 some minutes and in the end is just a throw away type of thing. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EPQ9EVQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 The only issue with these lenses is that they don't come in exactly at 38mm. The 3 I got are completely different sizes ranging between 39 and 41. Besides the issues with the size, they do work well when I watched a show on my phone for a few minutes using an app called Cinema VR. Now the next step I want to design a decent pair of goggles, something Google Cardboard-ish but perhaps with the diopter from OSVR, since their design works better for peeps with glasses. Also need it to be able to handle various phone sizes. One additional thing i want to include is a way to run wires in it for the headphone jack and possibly a OTG cable so I can hook up a mouse + keyboard while I have the goggles on. Freecad source included, You'll need em if you buy these lenses.
Lego Rhaegar part

What is PopPet? PopPet is a fun and easy to build educational robotics platform for all ages. The problem with many educational robotics platforms is that they restrict how much you can actually modify them. Most come pre-assembled and sealed, not allowing any access to the inner workings whatsoever. How can you learn robotics without knowing what makes up a robot? PopPet is different however. PopPet is a fully Open Hardware DIY robot kit that allows students or hobbyists alike to learn what goes into making a robot. Not only will you learn how to make a robot from scratch, you can also customize PopPet's looks to suit you by changing out the faceplate. One of the main design features of PopPet is the interchangeable faceplates. The faceplates allow PopPet to express different personalities or moods. Want PopPet to be suprised, sad, happy or even turn PopPet into a cat? There's faceplates for that! You can browse the store to view the ever expanding amount of faceplates on offer. What is the use of playing with a highly customizable and unique robot kit if you can't do any of your own customizing? Well, that is one of the main reasons why PopPet is an Open Hardware robot. The design plans have been released to allow you to make your own custom faceplates, add-ons, wheels or whatever else you can think of. PopPet is laser cut but not everyone has access to a laser cutter. Don't fret, PopPet can also be 3D printed! This makes it much easier to make your own PopPet. PopPet can do whatever you are capable of programming. Of course a lot of what PopPet can do is determined by what sensors she has. There are many mounting points for sensors all over PopPet. There are places to mount several line following modules, LED's, Light sensors and even a piezo buzzer. There are also many places to zip strap things onto, because we know how important zip straps are in the robot building process. Often robot kits are big and bulky making them difficult to transport, not PopPet! PopPet is just ever so slightly larger than a credit card! What's inside PopPet? Whilst PopPet does look great on the outside, it’s what’s in the inside that counts. In terms of actuation PopPet uses two Little Black Duck DC Motors. These LBD’s come in a servo form factor making them very easy to mount. They are quite quick and come with handy female jumper cable connectors. To ‘see’ PopPet uses the HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Distance Sensor. Using this sensor essentially means PopPet ‘sees’ just like a bat. It sends out an ultrasonic wave using one ‘eye’ and waits for it to return on the other. When this wave is heard we can calculate how far away an object is by using a simple mathematical formula. For the ‘brains’ PopPet uses the DAGU Mini Driver. This is a great board as it has a small form factor and has an on-board H-bridge. Having an H-Bridge on-board means we can control two DC motors without any additionally circuitry. What does PopPet do? PopPet can do whatever you want her to do, she is Arduino compatible meaning she can be programmed using the Arduino IDE. Here are some examples of things she can do.
Basic Obstacle Avoidance: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ACw1BnKGG8o
Advanced Obstacle Avoidance: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pFUh5UFoYp0
Clean up: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dVECQEoFPGo
Protect your belongings: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ToHgGBk-vEA
The Advanced kit can also follow light and respond to sound: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UYQ-drOfN1I
Build instructions available at: http://www.poppettherobot.com/getting-started.html For BOM visit: http://www.poppettherobot.com/open-source.html

title: J-head light rig for Prusa i3

description.text: This is another light setup for your extruder. The extruder baseline used was from Prusa i3 rework. The fanduct has been modeled to fit on the j head aluminium extruder body. The ring is an off-the-self 50mm ring for couple euros you have 2 pcs. http://www.ebay.de/itm/351196814296?ru=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ebay.de%2Fsch%2Fi.html%3F_from%3DR40%26ghostText%3D%26_sacat%3D0%26_nkw%3D351196814296%26_rdc%3D1 You can modify the openscad file to use smaller ring, for example 40mm, or to create a dual extrusion rig.

There is a pass through hole for the cable going to the light ring.
You can connect in parallel both the extruder fan and light ring (12VDC). The fan has screws that directly enter on the fanduct, no need for M3 nuts here. The 2 screws for the ring were added in case you want to remove the light ring for whatever reason.

title: Thermocouple sensor, single sided carrier board

description.text:
I wanted a proper board to mount the MAX6675 sensor discussed here: http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Hacks_to_the_RepRap_Extruder_Controller_v2.2 Datasheet is here: http://datasheets.maxim-ic.com/en/ds/MAX6675.pdf I haven't attempted to use it yet, but it etched cleanly and I had no trouble getting the chip to seat on the pads. There are pads to mount a .1uF capacitor as well, but damn those things are tiny and exactly the same dingy-beige as my carpet. I'm better with CAD than I am with Eagle, so I welcome a proper Eagle version if anyone wants to put in the time. Meanwhile, I'll be under my desk with a flashlight and a magnet hunting for capacitors.
Damnitallsomuch.
The DXF is mirrored for use in the toner-transfer method PCB fabrication.

title: FC & ESC holder for EMaglio's Mini FPV Tricopter

description.text:
As requested from my Make of EMaglio's FPV Mini Tricopter, here are the files for the Flightcontrol- and ESC-Holders.  
FC Holder is designed to fit a Naze32 (full or acro) in front of the body. To acces the USB port via the front left hole, simply mount the FC 90 degrees clockwise. When mounted via double sided sticky tape (not the foamy one), the height should be exactly right for the USB cable. Do not forget to change the board offset to 90 degree in BaseFlight (or CleanFlight). Mounting also requires 4 very short M3 bolts (4.5-5mm length).  
ESC Holder is designed to fit 3 stripped Emax 12A Simon Series ESC's.

Files are already "NetFabbed" and in right orientation for printing.  
Printed in PLA @ .2mm layer hight, 1 shell and 100% infill; should work without support.

The idea of this was a generator with that i can make fitting toghether sluiceboxes in every size, riffles in all possible shapes, classifiers that fit right in, mats with riffles, mats with extruded geometry and so on, all from one generator.
This is my idea of it. I am not a programmer and this is my third thing i made with Openscad, i know that not everything is written clean or simple or right, but like this it works for me and there is a lot of potential to add more things to the generator, like surface libraries for mats etc. , or waterconnections, fittings and tubes, or maybe underflowriffles, hydroriffles, fluidbed or even a trommel. Just everything you need to make a hole washplant.
You could add your own dxf file for riffles or extruded surface geometry
I know this can be made more dynamic in the future. I also know there could be a big mistake in it. If i made something stupid, don't be mad, help me make it better for the next version.
And if you find a design or combination that works very good you could post it for others to rebuild.

just put all files, exept the .stl in one place and start the generator in it. The generator can make a custom sluicebox with a channel, the fitting classifiers if desired, from plain mats to rifflemats in customizable sizes. You can make just single riffles or full length mats
First think of what you want to create. It is always good to make a quick freehand sketch of what your desired endresult should look like and how you can combine the parts the way you like. also think of what your printer or other machine is able to make.
Also several combinations are possible, like a mat with classifier, riffles and surfacepattern in one part
Sluiceboxchannels are most of the time too big for a home printer, but it is easy to make one, like buy a square pipe and cut it, nail some wood, bend sone metal or plastik ore take an existing sluicebox.
under the MAIN SETUP you can choose what to generate and under the PARAMETERS you put in your own values. You should use only one kind of mat at once. at least the wallthickness
To get starteted, pick one after the other to generate and play with the parameters, watch what values you put in, use some logic. MAIN SETUP
First choose what you want to generate
IMPORTANT: yes=Y, else 0 zero, the number
gen_sluicebox = y; //sluiceboxchannel
gen_classif = y; //classifier
gen_mat = 0; //plain mat
gen_uprifflemat = 0; //simple riffles
gen_roundrifflemat = y; //riffles made from two circles
gen_dxfrifflemat = 0; //dxf importet and extruded riffle-geometry on mat
gen_holemat = 0; //concave parts in the mat
gen_bumpmat = 0; //convex parts on the mat
gen_dxfgeometrymat = 0; //dxf importet and extruded geometry on mat
some combos are possible
END OF SETUP PARAM SLUICEBOX
Even if you don't create a sluiceboxchannel, you have to fill the values PARAM OF MATS
How long, wide and thick. PARAM CLASSIFIER
How high over the mat, what meshsize
here it important to know if you want to stack classifier over a mat, so its surface is cut by the classifier wall thickness. If you want the riffles all wide, set classifier wall to zero. PARAM OF RIFFLES
imported .dxf geometry
simple riffle is a square block
2 circle riffle, it is funny how many shapes and patterns can be made of just two circles. PARAM SURFACED MAT
customizable holes or depths in the mat
customizable bumps on the mat
.dxf importet and extruded geometry on the mat. DXF files for your own designs you could use
Keep it simple, try to use only the needed, no dimensions etc., just keep all in the position and watch your size of drawing, best to setup grid and draw on it.
When you draw your own riffle design to save as .dxf the lowest Y coordinate should be a little bit on minus,and rest of the drawing should be in the X positive range.
When you draw your own surface design to save as .dxf the midline of the drawing should be on Y zero and rest of the drawing should be in the X positive range.
save in R12 or R13
when you get the 2 manifold error check the position of your dxf I printed mine with 0.3 Nozzle in soft PLA without support, layer 0.125, 20% Infill

My Kossel kit had an acrylic spool holder that broke when I caught the power cord on it. So I needed a replacement. I modeled this in SketchUp.  
For 1kg rolls of filament that are up to 70mm wide.  
Snaps onto 2020 rail and mounts with an M3x12 screw and drop-in t nut.

Printed with a 0.4mm nozzle at .3mm layer height. 20% fill with two perimeters. No supports. Very solid to hold kilo roll.   
Needs one (1) M3x12 screw and an M3 drop-in t nut to mount in the 2020 extrusion.  
Add the screw and the t nut before you snap it onto the rail. Twist up towards the screw hole to remove if you for get the add the mounting screw.

description.text:
I love the Rane TTM57-SL but the stock fader caps do suck. They wear out quickly and then they fall off too easily. Plus they only come in black. Now with my fader cap replacement, you can print yourself some fader caps that have a very tight and very snug fit.  
You also have the added benefit that you can print them in any color you like. Now how can you beat that!?

You'll want to print a test to make sure these exact dimensions will print a tight fitting snug cap. It took my 5 tries to get exactly the fit and feel that was perfect. DO NOT print these so that you have to force them on with muscle, you will break your mixer if you do that. Mine are snug and will not fall off, but I also did not break my mixer putting them on. I printed with
.1 Layer Height
0% Infill (hollow)
2 shells
100 mm/s speed

!!! Currently under construction (...PAUSED for an unspecified period...). Content might be faulty and incomplete. This package will be gradually expanded to include additional content. If interested, please check regularly back here.!!! Do you know what Co.Me.Do. or CPv0 for Ultimaker 2 is? • Co.Me.Do. (CoolMeDown)...in short:
CPv0...The very first expansion for my Ultimaker 2, conceived principally so that the printer can be a little higher on my desk on the surface. This happened immediately after purchasing my Ultimaker 2, and I had no experience with the construction of 3D objects. But this printer had to stand on my desk, there was no other place. But the adjacent sill blocked the easy replacement of filament roles and I had to tinker quickly something useful to me. A short time later I integrated into this frame a PC fan controller which I use mainly for cooling all stepper motors and the system board. My latest addition is a digital Operating hours counter, with a self-designed housing...Of course, all optional components operate automatically, so I really need to worry only about the printer.
• The base is a very simple but sturdy frame for the Ultimaker 2, a framework for all possible extensions. I'm really looking forward to seeing what you make of it.
• Create side panels, drawers for accessories, frames for LCD screens and measurement tools, bracket for mounting the power supply, etc.
• Everything is printable, even the extruded profiles. For example you can halve all too long profiles, print, and reconnect with two clutches. But do not forget that two clutches require a total of 9 mm width.
• I cheated a bit and used Aluminum extruded profiles (20x20mm with 3xNut6 and one flat side) for this Frame. • Information regarding enhancements and bug fixes you will find in the "Comment" section. Photos with the already assembled object does not show the latest design.
• Again and again: My work for you lives solely by your feedback. If something is wrong or useless in my designs, I need more information from you so that I can ever change anything. Suggestions to improve or simplify my designs and descriptions are highly desirable. So if you use my designs and parts thereof, please take a few moments to convey a little feedback.

32x T-nuts with Nut6.

comments.text: You have done a good modelling job on this piece. That said, it has some layout issues which should be specified. This is not print ready. If you look at the joints, specifically each finger "knuckle", and the hinges (are they meant to be print in place?) the overlap when you laid them out merged a lot of the meshes together. This means that when printed, these areas are solid. In order to get connections that flex (as I assume you were going for based on the design), you have to delete the mesh in those areas and rebuild. To prevent this, you could either separate them a little further to prevent overlap, separate them completely and provide individual files or use a different connection. Great job on the rest of it though.

author: KevinR

description.text:
Jigsaw puzzle of India map with 3 levels of difficulty  
a) L0: India-map-base.stl (provides separate box like area for each state)  
b) L1: India-map-outlinebase.stl (provides just the outline of the map. Basically it helps keep all the pieces together and provides hint for some of the states location.  
c) L2: India-map.stl (just the set of state shape, put it together to make a complete map. This is bit tough in sapes don't have state name on it.

For level L0 and L1, you need to print the shape of all state (available in one single stl file) and one of the case. I have printed it see the picture, it prints really well. Though the India-map-outlinebase.stl doesn't seems to be 100% accurate in size, and requires some post processing filing job on some of states (the one that goes in corners GJ, JK and NE) and in the case too. I have combined some of the smaller states into one like all North Eastern states, as it would come out really tiny on my 140x140 printbed. if you want to design your own map here are the instruction, http://indusmaker.blogspot.co.uk/2013/07/3d-printed-jigsaw-puzzle.html

This should print without support or rafts if your printer is calibrated properly.  Peel it off your print bed and start looking good!

Awesome, and there are some weavers out there as evidenced by the rigid heddle loom print and the weaver's shuttle print.
